posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Week 0: What can we learn?

The line to configure the radios was long though. Didn’t take long for us, but a lot of teams hadn’t updated their firmware before the event.

Team Update 13 requires Radio Firmware 1.3.0, which was released on 2/14. If you haven’t updated your radio firmware after then, please do so now. There have been multiple fixes throughout the season to keep the radio from getting corrupted or stuck booting. Lets make sure the radio programming line goes smoothly by updating the firmware before your event.

180.79 KB

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
This. Please.

It is my understanding that events are preparing to put up an additional kiosk toughbook temporarily at some events to help alleviate any long lines at the kiosks.

If you can, please update to 1.3.0+ before your event - that is the fastest way to get your radio programmed quickly.

When at your event, if you can do so, remove the radio from the robot and send a student or two to the kiosk line as soon as possible. If possible, please avoid bringing up your whole robot – first, there likely will not be a lot of room near the kiosks for full robots, and second, you can continue to prepare your robot while waiting for your radio to get programmed.

If you are a team, like mine, that always prepared and programmed 2 radios (because the old radios were always so reliable), please wait to program the 2nd radio until after the rest of the teams have gotten their first one programmed.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
bdaroz:

please wait to program the 2nd radio until after the rest of the teams have gotten their first one programmed.

Is this really that big of a deal? I saw the line for the week zero event, but I’m not sure that sending a student to wait in that line twice is globally optimal (and surely isn’t optimal for them) and a team with two patched radios in hand can program the second radio in, what, a minute? (I’d imagine that teams who came prepared with two radios in a student’s hands have a high overlap with teams who are up to date on patches for the radios as well.)

Even if I was going to implement this policy, how would I possibly know when all the teams have their first radio programmed? (We’re a one-radio team, so it’s a thought exercise more than a practical one.)

I’m all for being kind and GP , but I don’t know that the global benefit here equals the global cost.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
bdaroz:

It is my understanding that events are preparing to put up an additional kiosk toughbook temporarily at some events to help alleviate any long lines at the kiosks.

teams can update their radio themselves? why are they lining up to update it there in the first place (only thing i can assume is that the kiosk software updates the radio automatically if it isnt 1.3.0)

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: If they didn’t see the PSA or didn’t update for whatever reason before the event, they likely won’t have WiFi at the event to do the update themselves.

posts.name: Quincy Tordil
posts.cooked:
nevadexehs:

(only thing i can assume is that the kiosk software updates the radio automatically if it isnt 1.3.0)

image 834×264 19.7 KB

image 834×264 19.7 KB

image 834×264 19.7 KB

You are correct, the kiosk(s) will automatically update the firmware if it is not already updated. This update has said to add a few minutes to each team trying to program their radio. I know the events I am going to are setting up at least two kiosks to try and help remedy the time in line being too long.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
At an event, all teams must use the radio kiosk in order to program their radios secret WPA key to connect to the field.

The radio kiosk also ensures the radio is updated to the latest firmware version.

Experience at our week zero event, we had three radio kiosks set up and to my knowledge programming was efficient.

Upgrading firmware took 2 to 3 minutes.

Programming the WPA key and SSID took approximately 1-2 minutes.

If you bring your robot radio already on the latest firmware, the kiosk will skip the firmware programming step and take you directly to the SSID and WPA key programming step.

Kudos to @kiettyyyy ! To be honest, I did not have experience with the prior radio programming kiosk, but the docker kiosks we set up for our week zero ran flawlessly! And I was impressed at how it stepped users through the programming experience and was very simple.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
Gasper1747:

You are correct, the kiosk(s) will automatically update the firmware if it is not already updated. This update has said to add a few minutes to each team trying to program their radio. I know the events I am going to are setting up at least two kiosks to try and help remedy the time in line being too long.

Jwal:

If you bring your robot radio already on the latest firmware, the kiosk will skip the firmware programming step and take you directly to the SSID and WPA key programming step.

alr that all makes sense now, its good that the vh team thought ahead about this

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
sokoloff:

Is this really that big of a deal? I saw the line for the week zero event, but I’m not sure that sending a student to wait in that line twice is globally optimal

The answer is… I really don’t know (yet). The only events we’ve had were Week 0s, and ISR #1, and I’ve asked in my training calls for any notes/data on kiosk delays (nor not) with the programming due to the 1.3.0 requirement, but there’s isn’t any to share…

I put it out there to ask teams to consider it. If you look at the kiosk line and it’s brutally long, perhaps the GP thing would be to defer the 2nd radio programming (especially if it also needs an upgrade) to let other teams get their first radio done so they can do what they need to do to get ready. If the lines are non-issues, or it’s a critical thing for your team (e.g. you’re short handed and can’t wait in the line again) by all means, drop 2 radios on there and get them all set up now.

There’s just not enough data on kiosk times - but concern enough HQ is asking us to put up a 2nd kiosk if at all possible for as long as possible.

Really, my hope is the vast majority of teams get 1.3.0 before the event, and this all becomes a complete non-issue.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
bdaroz:

or it’s a critical thing for your team (e.g. you’re short handed and can’t wait in the line again) by all means, drop 2 radios on there and get them all set up now.

I don’t think these teams are generally the ones bringing two radios, in my experience at least.

Regardless, the radio kiosks are up all event; spare parts has loaner radios if necessary, and they’d be pretty useless if you couldn’t configure them. The kiosk generally never has a line by opening ceremonies; plenty of time to configure the spare at your leisure from that point on.
